I expect that even with another $2trn in USD government stimulus, that it will have little impact on the value of the USD, and not create any inflationary effects on the currency - at least, not in the short term.

In the same way that Bitcoin has a dominance index in the cryptocurrency markets, the USD has one too.  Right now, even while issuing more dollars, the dominance of the USD is rising, which will offset inflationary effects as global trade is weighted more toward the USD.

Global money supply is over $70trn, but this includes all currencies. As the US dollar supply increases, it leverages Gresham's law to maintain stability when other countries create stimulus packages that pushes their economies to the brink, devaluing their currencies.

RT @WIRED: You may be hearing some people say that the flu is deadlier than the novel coronavirus; that‚Äôs because they don‚Äôt really underst‚Ä¶

The CDC has just issued it's first notice to stockpile medication and food  for the older population - and I don't think we're ready for a run on the reserves just yet: https://t.co/YJffr9vUdc\n\nTake action now and let's try to protect the generations that came before us.

This is why Italy has a much higher mortality rate - it's hit their aging population very hard and they are still not out the woods yet.  If you have anyone who is older than 50 and that you care about, I highly recommend that you start taking precautions immediately.

The point of concern and quarantine is to prevent the spread of the virus that could potentially kill millions of people who are 1-2 generations behind us, not to protect the 0-40 year olds who will most likely only suffer from mild symptoms and low mortality rates.

This blended number looks lowish (1-3%), but if you remove the sub 50 year olds from the denominator, the mortality rate skyrockets. If you think it's ok that your parents or elders die at a potential rate of 15-30% if they catch a highly infectious disease then stop reading now.

The broken logic thinking that Coronavirus  affects the older population disproportionately and therefore is not as deadly as the flu needs to be stopped.  The current mortality rate is a blended one. This means that we're looking at a mix of young and old people combined.

As we move into a new decade, I think it is important for us to appreciate that our reality of what is the truth may not be accurate. Keep an open mind and be respectful of people that challenge your most closely held beliefs. You might just learn something...

This allows us to invalidate previously held beliefs and discover truth. In reality though, people are ostracized for speaking the truth before it is a widely known or held belief (e.g Mandela). This leads to mob justice, if the incumbent believers will suffer from the truth.

Examples to ponder : Geocentricity, Flat Earth, Racism, Slavery, Dictatorships, Alchemy, etc. As a species, we are able to discover the truth over centuries through the passage of time and the ability to pass on knowledge from one generation to the next.

Truth is often just a function of time. Humans tend to have a short term view of the truth and therefore the perception of what is true or false cannot be deduced within our lifetimes or fragments of time within them.

RT @balajis: A number of profitable businesses have what we will in retrospect call a digital currency component. See also airline frequent‚Ä¶

This is similar to how mobile leapfrogged fixed line communications in other parts of the world like South Africa. Financial investors who assume banking has large untapped markets are likely to be disappointed with what lies ahead...

The more we try to deliver banking to the world, the more we are trying to sell solutions without trying to understand and solve problems that the rest of the world really have. Banking is not the solution. Being unbanked is not an undesirable state.

The term ‚Äúfinancial inclusion‚Äù is certainly more accurate. If we assume that the new financial rails will be built on crypto, it‚Äôs entirely reasonable to assume that the 2-3bn ‚Äúunbanked‚Äù will never have bank accounts but will be able to be financially included.

We need to stop using the term ‚Äúunbanked‚Äù as if ‚Äúbanking‚Äù is the solution. Let‚Äôs not assume the world needs everyone to have a bank account in order to be able to function within society. What the world needs is the ability for every human to be able to transact effortlessly.

As the crypto industry evolves, I think we can expect security tokens to begin to hit the mainstream as alternative ways to finance network effect opportunities that can provide yields to investors, which will complement or enhance some of the existing utility token models.
Crypto has had many bubbles already, but as the industry moves towards things like security tokens that have yield curves, bubbles are unlikely to form in those sub-asset classes.

That being said, the rewards will likely be far greater than during the dotcom bubble/bust cycle, where the winners (FAANG) are now among the biggest companies in the world. Interesting point to note though, was that there was only one dotcom bubble.

The crypto economy is allowing entrepreneurs to build products and services that could never be financed via traditional mechanisms (equity, VC, debt, etc) because the success rates will likely be much lower.

That said, if we can break $6200 for BTC, it will likely mark the start of another major bull run and could run hot and high, but if it‚Äôs pure speculation and other assets benefit disproportionately to value created, it‚Äôs likely not going to end well again!

The key indicator for the start of a sustainable bull run is likely a decoupling of asset values from Bitcoin (i.e. Bitcoin‚Äôs strength weakens other networks or vice versa). Anything else is just speculation again (maybe we need another bubble to learn more lessons? üòâüòÇ)...

This makes no sense. How can we have a situation where the market price of one asset dictates the value ascribed to other unrelated assets ,irrespective of whether or not anything changes in their own separate networks.

So, even if the Bitcoin network effect or store of value hypothesis results in an increased price, this currently translates into broader market based upon sentiment, not fundamentals. So in practice, other cryptos get a boost from any improvements in Bitcoin fundamentals today.

It‚Äôs easy to argue that Bitcoin can be worth $10k or $20k, or even $100k, but the problem is that as the price has been rising towards those levels, we‚Äôre not seeing Bitcoin dominance increase disproportionately.

This means that as the Bitcoin price rises, so does the price of other crypto‚Äôs, irrespective of value. This is a key point - Bitcoin could double overnight, but does this mean other assets should too, even if nothing has changed on their end in term of development, network etc?

Many people believe that the crypto winter is over. Here are some of my unfiltered thoughts on this topic. Charts & technicals aside, I don‚Äôt believe this rally is sustainable for one reason: The market has not yet decoupled the various crypto assets from Bitcoin.

In the spirit of decentralization, it‚Äôs probably better that the world eventually has multiple at scale crypto currencies to rely on, rather than a single one, in the same way that we have USD, GBP, EUR, etc. Time will tell...

So while BTC, BSV and BCH communities fight it out for existing market share, we may have to contemplate that we will live in a world where there are a few major crypto currencies catering for different needs, including upcoming competitors like Facebook.

I also don‚Äôt have a religious belief that Bitcoin is pre-ordained to be the best digital money for the world and can never be beaten but it‚Äôs clear that the underlying Bitcoin technology is better suited to being money and being used for P2P payments than say, Ethereum or Ripple.
Ultimately the early miner (who may or may not be Satoshi) with the 1m+ coins, will have a strong say in influencing which fork ultimately wins, if they ever resurface. But, for now, BTC is Bitcoin.

All said and done, I‚Äôm an observer and my opinion does not matter and I cannot control the outcomes here. Que sera sera. These are just my humble thoughts. So if you ask me which Bitcoin I support - it‚Äôs the one that wins over the long term and is still around 10 years from now.

BSV supporters, in opposition to CTOR should have instead mined the original BCH chain and not simultaneously increased the blocksize at that point in time. This would have probably resulted in the BCH community not fracturing into two forks, imho.

BCH should not have implemented CTOR in a hurry, especially given the clear contentiousness within a small community and they should have tried to keep the community together, instead of fracturing further.

BTC should have increased the block size. Clearly LN was not going to be ready ‚Äúin 18 months‚Äù as claimed over 2 years ago. ‚ÄúStore of Value‚Äù hypothesis is flawed sub-scale and getting to scale is limited by the block size, possibly a catch-22. Merchant adoption has been stunted.

This battle may play out over the coming months and years, but for now BTC is clearly Bitcoin. That said, these are just my thoughts as to where I believe the communities went wrong and why I‚Äôm very agnostic right now.

BCH and BSV could not resolve their respective differences and this resulted in a clear rejection by the market which reflects in the price. Right now BCH is in the lead and one of these forks would need to establish a clear lead on the other before either could challenge BTC.

BTC is the clear winner and incumbent and it‚Äôs going to take a Herculean effort for BCH and BSV to overtake it. That said, the over-reliance on lightning network for scaling and extreme focus on decentralization with the risk of high fees at any moment is a major limiting factor.
Right now, I‚Äôm agnostic on all three forks for various reasons, but specifically, as it relates to how the various communities relay their world views and try to compete.
The main forks (BTC, BCH and BSV) are all competing to solve problems relating to a combination of scale, utility, adoption and security, amongst other goals.

Outside of BTC, BCH and BSV - the other forks are largely unsupported with tiny communities that have little chance of longevity and are, by and large, either outright scams or very poor attempts at forking a protocol and building community & adoption. They may survive sub-scale.

I don‚Äôt think I‚Äôve been clear on my thoughts on Bitcoin and the various forks, so here is a quick summary. I still believe peer to peer digital cash will win over ‚ÄúStore of Value‚Äù, but that doesn‚Äôt necessarily mean that it‚Äôs BCH or BSV.

The end state is that if we don‚Äôt want a repeat of the bubble/bust cycle, we need to focus on real adoption and use cases, and creating industrial demand for crypto. Prices will then track usage and we can get to a point where we can develop real metrics to trade against.

The skill gap basically means that traders and speculators want to make money based on market movements, without regard for underlying value creation or how it even gets created. This results in the creation of both FUD and fake news to help create volatility.

There is a large skill/knowledge gap between observers/speculators/traders and builders. Those who are building need to keep their heads down and continue to execute. Traders will trade & the market will judge the best projects in the long term, so ignore the short term sentiment

This is just a thesis linked to how things starts to decouple and we have a healthier, functional global crypto market. A solid foundation will aid us immensely in building towards the next bull market run - which could take months or years. I prefer that we clean up before then!

When depositors do a run on a particular coin, and want to move to risk free exchanges with higher prices, the fractional exchanges will have to deliver those coins to their customers and if they can‚Äôt that‚Äôs when it all begins to unravel...

I‚Äôve been very suspicious of the fake trade volumes that have been showing up. As more and more legit and regulated exchanges start trading crypto, it will cause a real supply demand imbalance and a run on the exchanges, so to speak. That‚Äôs when things get really interesting.

In the meantime, to all those building real value - keep your heads down and ignore the noise. Long term fundamentals matter - in good times and bad. Survivors can ultimately become winners.

The biggest risk now is that a 10x run on a $400bn is basically going to create $4trn in fictional value if it‚Äôs not driven by fundamentals. That‚Äôs a recipe for disaster. I‚Äôm hopefully we can avoid it, but I fear we won‚Äôt.

So, like I said previously, the longer the markets are bearish the better. It gives us time to consolidate, build and grow so that when the next run happens, it‚Äôs based on real value not future speculation of value (as the current one is).

I‚Äôm hoping that we can quickly build real value in the crypto economy and start growing the global economy at a faster pace by disrupting the old with the new and unlocking value in society. Speculation alone will not do this - we need real world applications and usage.

Again, my views are predicated on the fact that relative to the size of the crypto economy there is very little value add to the real world economies still. Disruption takes time but greed and fomo are impatient. When these two collide, the best and worst come to the fore.

If you think you‚Äôve seen regulators getting rough, wait till you see what happens if we go 5-10x+ from here in less than a year and then crashing down 80%+. The ensuing fallout could send us into a global recession.
However, if the speculative mania gets worse and we go from <$500bn to $5bn+ without sufficient infrastructure, utility and usage, when that bubble bursts it will wreak havoc upon the global economy.
I don‚Äôt think crypto is in an unsustainable bubble right now. If we go sideways for the next 12-18 months it will be healthy as it gives the technologists time to build product and adoption.
